timeline.message:
Efficient BytBuf search algorithms (#9914)

Motivation:

We have found out that ByteBufUtil.indexOf can be inefficient for substring search on
ByteBuf, both in terms of algorithm complexity (worst case O(needle.readableBytes *
haystack.readableBytes)), and in constant factor (esp. on Composite buffers).
With implementation of more performant search algorithms we have seen improvements on
the order of magnitude.

Modifications:

This change introduces three search algorithms:
1. Knuth Morris Pratt - classical textbook algorithm, a good default choice.
2. Bit mask based algorithm - stable performance on any input, but limited to maximum
search substring (the needle) length of 64 bytes.
3. Aho–Corasick - worse performance and higher memory consumption than [1] and [2], but
it supports multiple substring (the needles) search simultaneously, by inspecting every
byte of the haystack only once.

Each algorithm processes every byte of underlying buffer only once, they are implemented
as ByteProcessor.

Result:

Efficient search algorithms with linear time complexity available in Netty (I will share
benchmark results in a comment on a PR).
Improved benchmarks
Added PREDICTABLE and UNPREDICTABLE benchmark inputs
Adjusted some benchmark inputs
Minor polishing
Rename next to jumpTable in KMP
Cleaner AhoCorasic (no change in benchmarks)

timeline.bodyText: have you tried inspecting ASM here? Look if there is any PlatformDependent method that can save bound checks there.
timeline.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText:
@franz1981 I've checked the assembly, also tried Byte.toUnsignedInt (which I think intrinsics to movzbl), nothing has helped to eliminate the bounds check. JDK 8 / 11 / 13 / GraalVM.
Looks like PlatformDependent.getLong is something worth trying, thanks for the tip - will update later.
replies.author: linasm

replies.bodyText:
So, adding this to PlatformDependent0:
    static long getLong(long[] data, int index) {
        return UNSAFE.getLong(data, LONG_ARRAY_BASE_OFFSET + LONG_ARRAY_INDEX_SCALE * index);
    }
and using it in ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor gives 2-8% improvement.
Assembly with Array (process method is inlined and 4x loop-unrolled, so I'm only pasting one unroll piece here):
  2.36%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c791e: movzx  r9d,BYTE PTR [rbx+rcx*1+0x12]
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ;*iand
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@17 (line 37)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  0.70%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c7924: mov    rax,rdx
  2.69%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c7927: shl    rax,1
  0.78%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c792a: mov    r8d,r10d
  1.85%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c792d: add    r8d,0x2            ;*iinc
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@21 (line 1335)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  0.91%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c7931: or     rax,0x1            ;*lor  ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@8 (line 37)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ ││  │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  2.84%  │  │ ││  │      0x000000010a0c7935: cmp    r9d,esi
         │  │ ││╭ │      0x000000010a0c7938: jae    0x000000010a0c79ef  ;*laload
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@18 (line 37)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  0.53%  │  │ │││ │      0x000000010a0c793e: and    rax,QWORD PTR [rbp+r9*8+0x10]
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ;*land
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@19 (line 37)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  2.55%  │  │ │││ │      0x000000010a0c7943: mov    r9,rax
  0.81%  │  │ │││ │      0x000000010a0c7946: and    r9,r13             ;*land
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@31 (line 38)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │  │ │││ │                                                    ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  3.31%  │  │ │││ │      0x000000010a0c7949: test   r9,r9
         │  │ │││ │      0x000000010a0c794c: jne    0x000000010a0c7a43  ;*ifne

(bound check is cmp r9d,esi; jae)
Assembly with Unsafe (again, 1/4 piece of loop unroll):
  6.95%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc973: shl    rbx,1
  0.33%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc976: movsxd rax,r10d
  0.26%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc979: movzx  esi,BYTE PTR [rdi+rax*1+0x11]
         │     │                                                  ;*iand
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@17 (line 36)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  0.11%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc97e: or     rbx,0x1
  6.88%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc982: and    rbx,QWORD PTR [rdx+rsi*8+0x10]
         │     │                                                  ;*land
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@21 (line 36)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  1.56%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc987: mov    rsi,rbx
  0.42%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc98a: and    rsi,r8             ;*land
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.search.ShiftingBitMaskSearchProcessor::process@33 (line 38)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByteAsc0@11 (line 1336)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf::forEachByte@14 (line 1316)
         │     │                                                  ; - io.netty.microbench.search.SearchBenchmark::shiftingBitMask@11 (line 197)
  6.74%  │     │    0x000000010c2cc98d: test   rsi,rsi
         │   ╭ │    0x000000010c2cc990: jne    0x000000010c2cca19  ;*ifne

(which looks really good to me, except for maybe some instruction ordering)
Of course, same change could be done for KMP and Aho-Corasic (requiring to add getInt and getObject to PlatformDependent).
replies.author: linasm

replies.bodyText: Tried PlatformDependent with all algos. Up to 8% improvement for Shifting bit mask, up to +21% for KMP, no measurable change for Aho-Corasic. Looks like Aho-Corasic is hitting some hard CPU pipeline limit, caused by tight traversal of this 2 level cyclic memory access indirection (object -> array -> object). Currently trying to resolve this issue, with promising results. Once done, will update with full table of results (want to avoid excess noise here).
replies.author: linasm

timeline.message: PlatformDependent same type array based getInt and getLong

timeline.bodyText:
It cannot be made less GC hungry by caching the search processor?
each benchmarked method could include the jump table initialization and needle clone too (thinking of kmp here)
Escape analysis probably won't even kick-in due to the size of needle array
timeline.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText: Sure, I can make the runs allocation free by reusing the search processor (resetting its state is trivial for all algos). Or is it something else that you had in mind?
replies.author: linasm

replies.bodyText: My new benchmark suite will reuse (reset) the SearchProcessor so each invocation will be allocation free.
replies.author: linasm

timeline.message: ShiftingBitMask and KMP using PlatformDependent instead of array
Rewrite Aho-Corasic for better performance
SearchProcessor.reset method
Missed one array access in KMP - replace with PlatformDependent.getByte
Use PlatformDependent.getXX with long index in all string search algos
Expand byte to long instead of int in AhoCorasic
A new benchmark suite - SearchRealDataBenchmark
Do not reuse SearchProcessor in SearchRealDataBenchmark
Fix typo
Rename ShiftingBitMask to Bitap (as known in the industry)
Nest SearchProcessor classes in their Factories for a more compact code
Additional test cases
